messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:40): Opera actually shows EXIF data if you rightclick an image and hit properties
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:41): seems that Flickr removes it for everything but the original photo though
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:44): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, thanks for http://weblogs.mozillazine.org 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427/archives/2008/09/some_boring_css.html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:44): earliest mention of me seems to be:

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:44): Aug 16, 1999 -  "I am quite happy to work for mozilla just to get a decent, free, standards compliant browser onto the market," said Ian Hickson, a Web developer from the UK who contributed to the mozilla BugAThon project. "That is an incentive in itself, the rest is just a bonus."
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:44): filed that long ago
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:44): (earliest mention in actual news, anyway)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:44): Google claims my about page is the earliest mention of me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:44): i was 19 at the time. i was a random student, not a "Web developer from the UK"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:45): hah

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:51): I don't think I ever positioned the root element for any purpose, but positioning the body element against the root element that has a border was something I tried
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:51): (which then failed in Firefox at which point I filed that bug)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:53): when you filed the bug I don't think anyone except Opera got it right
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:55): yeah

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:58): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: your input on http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/ietf-http-wg/2008JulSep/0441.html would be very welcome
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:59): if there's someone in your respective organisations i should ping in particular, i'd be happy to do so, just let me know
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:59): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: interesting
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:59): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: any quantitative results available?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:00): the numbers vary a lot based on the kind of page, from what i understand
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I am interested in how much it saves compared to gzip compression
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: or other straightforward compression schemes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:01): well, for a page like, say, the google results page, gzip can only compress the page, whereas this can compress the header and footer parts dramatically
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:02): I see a slide deck, guess I will look at that
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:02): sure it sounds interesting in theory
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:02): the proposal is in the PDF
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:02): About 40 percent data reduction better than Gzip alone on Google search.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:02): I would like to see numbers
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:02): See faster Google search results. Especially under low bandwidth and high latency condition.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:02): i shall poke for numbers
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:02): preferably on a wide range of sites
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:03): having a per-site compression index does carry some risks
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:03): complexity, new attack surface, etc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:03): for sure
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:03): but it also sounds in theory like it could be a big win
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:03): Also it'd be interesting to compare to gzip with a preset dictionary
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:03): in principle it sounds good
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:03): true, a preset dictionary for the general web including common html and css constructs might be a big win too
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:04): this could subsume that if you allow Access-Controls on dictionaries
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:05): (Also maybe to gzip of multi-request/response keepalived stream (i.e. compress the whole stream, not just each response separately))
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:05): and btw I am specifically interested in perf on a large variety of realistic examples, not just the best-case examples
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:05): yeah
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:05): (or else convincing argument that best case is very common)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:05): search pages are pretty common
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:05): Maybe we could just hardcode Google's header and footer into all UAs
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:06): I would hope it is more broadly applicable than google search result pages
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:08): the paper mentioned in the e-mail is here: http://sdch.googlegroups.com/web/Shared_Dictionary_Compression_over_HTTP.pdf
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:11): with this design, you can't actually share dictionaries across domains, because that would open an DoS attack against other sites
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:11): well, at least a reduction in performance
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:12): so how do I give feedback?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): reply on the list
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): (the http list, that is)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): i don't really know where the right place to standardise this would be if y'all are interested in taking this further
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): probably a new w3c or ietf wg
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): (no idea how the ietf works)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): oh, he also attached the PDF, i totally didn't notice
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:20): http://trac.webkit.org/changeset/36097 is funny
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:28): finds a part of wf2 that requires browsers to implement time travel
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:28): paradox-avoiding time travel, even
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:36): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I hope you didn't remove it, I was depending on that feature in my new awesome framework
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:39): ok i need a word for what we do to check the validity of a form that isn't "validity"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:40): since we use that for conformance
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:40): constraint cecking maybe
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:40): checking
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:41): Constraint is good.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:41): Filled-inedness
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): takes ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c's merit badge back
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): you now have -1 merit badges. :-P
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:42): User cooperation ensurance
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): hah
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:42): Is ensurance a word?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:43): you guys realise i now have to use both of these ideas in the spec somehow right
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:43): I will deny everything
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:43): i have logs!
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:44): I could claim impersonation
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:44): mmm.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:44): bummer.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:45): This is where you're supposed to vaguely hint to some kind of vast google conspiracy to control and monitor all traffic on the net
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:45): oh right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:45): "google doesn't comment on future products and services"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:47): I suppose I should try to at least pretend I sleep at sane times, as I'm not being paid to stay awake at night.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:49): if you get paid for your work instead of your ass-in-a-chair-ness, then you can just work at night
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:53): Yeah, but even if I did go to the university at midnight, I doubt any students would show up to get help :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:53): ah well
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:54): that i can't help you with
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:54): i recommend getting students to ask for help by e-mail
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:54): Not like they show up in daytime either...
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:54): Yeah, tried that too. Maybe it'll pick up when the exercises get harder.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:55): When I took the course myself, I did email my predecessor quite a bit
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:02): If the exercises are easy, they can do them without any help; if the exercises are hard, they won't do them at all and will instead play frisbee or whatever
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:04): isn't quite sure what lazy students do nowadays
